mn70:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kāsīsu cārikaṃ carati mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ.
mn70:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kāsis together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.

mn70:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

mn70:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, I abstain from eating at night.
mn70:2.1.comm: While I have not been able to trace a Jain rule regarding eating in the afternoon, not eating at night (rattibhojanā) was a standard practice of Jain ascetics (Uttarādhyayana 19.30, 13.2; Dasaveyāliya 4.6, 6.26; Sūyagaḍa 1.2.3.3). It was adopted early into the Gradual Training (MN 27:13.9). The failure of mendicants to comply led to the laying down of a formal Vinaya rule (Bu Pc 37). But some came to regret their objections, recognizing that the Buddha had acted for their welfare (MN 66:6.4). | The related practice of eating in one sitting is, by contrast, not required in the Vinaya, but was encouraged (MN 21:7.4, MN 65:2.1).

mn70:2.2.pli: Aññatra kho panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, rattibhojanā bhuñjamāno appābādhatañca sañjānāmi appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañca.
mn70:2.2.eng: Doing so, I find that I’m healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.

mn70:2.3.pli: Etha, tumhepi, bhikkhave, aññatreva rattibhojanā bhuñjatha.
mn70:2.3.eng: You too should abstain from eating at night.

mn70:2.4.pli: Aññatra kho pana, bhikkhave, tumhepi rattibhojanā bhuñjamānā appābādhatañca sañjānissatha appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañcā”ti.
mn70:2.4.eng: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”

mn70:2.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

mn70:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā kāsīsu anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena kīṭāgiri nāma kāsīnaṃ nigamo tadavasari.
mn70:3.1.eng: Then the Buddha, traveling stage by stage in the land of the Kāsis, arrived at a town of the Kāsis named Kīṭāgiri,

mn70:3.2.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā kīṭāgirismiṃ viharati kāsīnaṃ nigame.

mn70:4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena assajipunabbasukā nāma bhikkhū kīṭāgirismiṃ āvāsikā honti.
mn70:4.1.eng: Now at that time the mendicants who followed Assaji and Punabbasuka were residing at Kīṭāgiri.
mn70:4.1.comm: Assaji and Punabbasuka were a pair of shameless monks known for corrupting lay folk with their superficial charm (Bu Ss 13:1.1.2, Kd 11:13.1.1) and for misdirecting Sangha lodgings (Kd 16:16.1.1), while leading others down the same path. | Assaji is not to be confused with the good monk who was one of the first five mendicants (MN 35:3.1).

mn70:4.2.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena assajipunabbasukā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā assajipunabbasuke bhikkhū etadavocuṃ:
mn70:4.2.eng: Then several mendicants went up to them and said,

mn70:4.3.pli: “bhagavā kho, āvuso, aññatreva rattibhojanā bhuñjati bhikkhusaṅgho ca.
mn70:4.3.eng: “Reverends, the Buddha abstains from eating at night, and so does the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn70:4.4.pli: Aññatra kho panāvuso, rattibhojanā bhuñjamānā appābādhatañca sañjānanti appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañca.
mn70:4.4.eng: Doing so, they find that they’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.

mn70:4.5.pli: Etha, tumhepi, āvuso, aññatreva rattibhojanā bhuñjatha.
mn70:4.5.eng: You too should abstain from eating at night.

mn70:4.6.pli: Aññatra kho panāvuso, tumhepi rattibhojanā bhuñjamānā appābādhatañca sañjānissatha appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañcā”ti.
mn70:4.6.eng: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”

mn70:4.7.pli: Evaṃ vutte, assajipunabbasukā bhikkhū te bhikkhū etadavocuṃ:
mn70:4.7.eng: When they said this, the mendicants who followed Assaji and Punabbasuka said to them,

mn70:4.8.pli: “mayaṃ kho, āvuso, sāyañceva bhuñjāma pāto ca divā ca vikāle.
mn70:4.8.eng: “Reverends, we eat at dusk, at daybreak, and at the wrong time of day.

mn70:4.9.pli: Te mayaṃ sāyañceva bhuñjamānā pāto ca divā ca vikāle appābādhatañca sañjānāma appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañca.
mn70:4.9.eng: Doing so, we find that we’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.

mn70:4.10.pli: Te mayaṃ kiṃ sandiṭṭhikaṃ hitvā kālikaṃ anudhāvissāma?
mn70:4.10.eng: Why should we give up what is apparent in the present to chase after what takes effect over time?
mn70:4.10.comm: They are twisting the meaning of well-known properties of the Dhamma, which is “apparent in the present” and “immediately effective” (sandiṭṭhiko akāliko, MN 7:6.2). In this they are following the example of Māra, who makes the exact same argument (SN 1.20:4.4, SN 4.21:1.7). The fallacy is that it is sensual pleasures that take time—for they bind you to rebirth—whereas the Dhamma may be realized in this life.

mn70:4.11.pli: Sāyañceva mayaṃ bhuñjissāma pāto ca divā ca vikāle”ti.
mn70:4.11.eng: We shall eat at dusk, at daybreak, and at the wrong time of day.”

mn70:5.1.pli: Yato kho te bhikkhū nāsakkhiṃsu assajipunabbasuke bhikkhū saññāpetuṃ, atha yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn70:5.1.eng: Since those mendicants were unable to persuade the mendicants who were followers of Assaji and Punabbasuka, they approached the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

mn70:5.2.pli: “idha mayaṃ, bhante, yena assajipunabbasukā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkamimha; upasaṅkamitvā assajipunabbasuke bhikkhū etadavocumha:

mn70:5.3.pli: ‘bhagavā kho, āvuso, aññatreva rattibhojanā bhuñjati bhikkhusaṅgho ca;

mn70:5.4.pli: aññatra kho panāvuso, rattibhojanā bhuñjamānā appābādhatañca sañjānanti appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañca.

mn70:5.5.pli: Etha, tumhepi, āvuso, aññatreva rattibhojanā bhuñjatha.

mn70:5.6.pli: Aññatra kho panāvuso, tumhepi rattibhojanā bhuñjamānā appābādhatañca sañjānissatha appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañcā’ti.

mn70:5.7.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, assajipunabbasukā bhikkhū amhe etadavocuṃ:

mn70:5.8.pli: ‘mayaṃ kho, āvuso, sāyañceva bhuñjāma pāto ca divā ca vikāle.

mn70:5.9.pli: Te mayaṃ sāyañceva bhuñjamānā pāto ca divā ca vikāle appābādhatañca sañjānāma appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañca.

mn70:5.10.pli: Te mayaṃ kiṃ sandiṭṭhikaṃ hitvā kālikaṃ anudhāvissāma?

mn70:5.11.pli: Sāyañceva mayaṃ bhuñjissāma pāto ca divā ca vikāle’ti.

mn70:5.12.pli: Yato kho mayaṃ, bhante, nāsakkhimha assajipunabbasuke bhikkhū saññāpetuṃ, atha mayaṃ etamatthaṃ bhagavato ārocemā”ti.

mn70:6.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantesi:
mn70:6.1.eng: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,

mn70:6.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mama vacanena assajipunabbasuke bhikkhū āmantehi:
mn70:6.2.eng: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicants who follow Assaji and Punabbasuka that

mn70:6.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato paṭissutvā yena assajipunabbasukā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā assajipunabbasuke bhikkhū etadavoca:
mn70:6.4.eng: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to those mendicants and said,

mn70:6.6.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho assajipunabbasukā bhikkhū tassa bhikkhuno paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho assajipunabbasuke bhikkhū bhagavā etadavoca:
mn70:6.6.eng: “Yes, reverend,” those mendicants replied. They went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.

mn70:6.7.pli: “saccaṃ kira, bhikkhave, sambahulā bhikkhū tumhe upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṃ:
mn70:6.7.eng: The Buddha said to them, “Is it really true, mendicants, that several mendicants went to you and said:

mn70:6.8.pli: ‘bhagavā kho, āvuso, aññatreva rattibhojanā bhuñjati bhikkhusaṅgho ca.
mn70:6.8.eng: ‘Reverends, the Buddha abstains from eating at night, and so does the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn70:6.9.pli: Aññatra kho panāvuso, rattibhojanā bhuñjamānā appābādhatañca sañjānanti appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañca.
mn70:6.9.eng: Doing so, they find that they’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.

mn70:6.10.pli: Etha, tumhepi, āvuso, aññatreva rattibhojanā bhuñjatha.
mn70:6.10.eng: You too should abstain from eating at night.

mn70:6.11.pli: Aññatra kho panāvuso, tumhepi rattibhojanā bhuñjamānā appābādhatañca sañjānissatha appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañcā’ti.
mn70:6.11.eng: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.’

mn70:6.12.pli: Evaṃ vutte, kira, bhikkhave, tumhe te bhikkhū evaṃ avacuttha:
mn70:6.12.eng: When they said this, did you really say to them:

mn70:6.13.pli: ‘mayaṃ kho panāvuso, sāyañceva bhuñjāma pāto ca divā ca vikāle.
mn70:6.13.eng: ‘Reverends, we eat at dusk, at daybreak, and at the wrong time of day.

mn70:6.14.pli: Te mayaṃ sāyañceva bhuñjamānā pāto ca divā ca vikāle appābādhatañca sañjānāma appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañca.
mn70:6.14.eng: Doing so, we find that we’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.

mn70:6.15.pli: Te mayaṃ kiṃ sandiṭṭhikaṃ hitvā kālikaṃ anudhāvissāma?
mn70:6.15.eng: Why should we give up what is apparent in the present to chase after what takes effect over time?

mn70:6.16.pli: Sāyañceva mayaṃ bhuñjissāma pāto ca divā ca vikāle’”ti.
mn70:6.16.eng: We shall eat at dusk, at daybreak, and at the wrong time of day.’”

mn70:6.18.pli: “Kiṃ nu me tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṃ dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānātha yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tassa akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī”ti?
mn70:6.18.eng: “Mendicants, have you ever known me to teach the Dhamma like this: no matter what this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—their unskillful qualities decline and their skillful qualities grow?”
mn70:6.18.comm: The Buddha, even in the face of such intransigence, begins by establishing common ground and giving encouragement.

mn70:7.1.pli: “Nanu me tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṃ dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānātha idhekaccassa yaṃ evarūpaṃ sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, idha panekaccassa evarūpaṃ sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, idhekaccassa evarūpaṃ dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, idha panekaccassa evarūpaṃ dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, idhekaccassa evarūpaṃ adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, idha panekaccassa evarūpaṃ adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī”ti?
mn70:7.1.eng: “Haven’t you known me to teach the Dhamma like this: ‘When someone feels this kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline. But when someone feels that kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow. When someone feels this kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline. But when someone feels that kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow. When someone feels this kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline. But when someone feels that kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow’?”

mn70:8.2.pli: Mayā cetaṃ, bhikkhave, aññātaṃ abhavissa adiṭṭhaṃ aviditaṃ asacchikataṃ aphassitaṃ paññāya:
mn70:8.2.eng: Now, suppose I hadn’t known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom:
mn70:8.2.comm: Having found an initial common ground, the Buddha takes time to establish that his teaching is grounded on experience.

mn70:8.3.pli: ‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṃ sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti,
mn70:8.3.eng: ‘When someone feels this kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’

mn70:8.4.pli: evāhaṃ ajānanto ‘evarūpaṃ sukhaṃ vedanaṃ pajahathā’ti vadeyyaṃ; api nu me etaṃ, bhikkhave, patirūpaṃ abhavissā”ti?
mn70:8.4.eng: Not knowing this, would it be appropriate for me to say: ‘You should give up this kind of pleasant feeling’?”

mn70:8.6.pli: “Yasmā ca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, mayā ñātaṃ diṭṭhaṃ viditaṃ sacchikataṃ phassitaṃ paññāya:
mn70:8.6.eng: “But I have known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom:

mn70:8.7.pli: ‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṃ sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, tasmāhaṃ ‘evarūpaṃ sukhaṃ vedanaṃ pajahathā’ti vadāmi.
mn70:8.7.eng: ‘When someone feels this kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’ Since this is so, that’s why I say: ‘You should give up this kind of pleasant feeling.’

mn70:8.8.pli: Mayā cetaṃ, bhikkhave, aññātaṃ abhavissa adiṭṭhaṃ aviditaṃ asacchikataṃ aphassitaṃ paññāya:
mn70:8.8.eng: Now, suppose I hadn’t known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom:

mn70:8.9.pli: ‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṃ sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evāhaṃ ajānanto ‘evarūpaṃ sukhaṃ vedanaṃ upasampajja viharathā’ti vadeyyaṃ;
mn70:8.9.eng: ‘When someone feels that kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.’

mn70:8.10.pli: api nu me etaṃ, bhikkhave, patirūpaṃ abhavissā”ti?
mn70:8.10.eng: Not knowing this, would it be appropriate for me to say: ‘You should enter and remain in that kind of pleasant feeling’?”

mn70:8.12.pli: “Yasmā ca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, mayā ñātaṃ diṭṭhaṃ viditaṃ sacchikataṃ phassitaṃ paññāya:
mn70:8.12.eng: “But I have known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom:

mn70:8.13.pli: ‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṃ sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, tasmāhaṃ ‘evarūpaṃ sukhaṃ vedanaṃ upasampajja viharathā’ti vadāmi.
mn70:8.13.eng: ‘When someone feels that kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.’ Since this is so, that’s why I say: ‘You should enter and remain in that kind of pleasant feeling.’

mn70:8.14.pli: Mayā cetaṃ, bhikkhave, aññātaṃ abhavissa adiṭṭhaṃ aviditaṃ asacchikataṃ aphassitaṃ paññāya:
mn70:8.14.eng: Now, suppose I hadn’t known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom:

mn70:8.15.pli: ‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṃ dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evāhaṃ ajānanto ‘evarūpaṃ dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ pajahathā’ti vadeyyaṃ;
mn70:8.15.eng: ‘When someone feels this kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’

mn70:8.16.pli: api nu me etaṃ, bhikkhave, patirūpaṃ abhavissā”ti?
mn70:8.16.eng: Not knowing this, would it be appropriate for me to say: ‘You should give up this kind of painful feeling’?”

mn70:9.1.pli: “Yasmā ca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, mayā ñātaṃ diṭṭhaṃ viditaṃ sacchikataṃ phassitaṃ paññāya:
mn70:9.1.eng: “But I have known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom:

mn70:9.2.pli: ‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṃ dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, tasmāhaṃ ‘evarūpaṃ dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ pajahathā’ti vadāmi.
mn70:9.2.eng: ‘When someone feels this kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’ Since this is so, that’s why I say: ‘You should give up this kind of painful feeling.’

mn70:9.3.pli: Mayā cetaṃ, bhikkhave, aññātaṃ abhavissa adiṭṭhaṃ aviditaṃ asacchikataṃ aphassitaṃ paññāya:
mn70:9.3.eng: Now, suppose I hadn’t known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom:

mn70:9.4.pli: ‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṃ dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evāhaṃ ajānanto ‘evarūpaṃ dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ upasampajja viharathā’ti vadeyyaṃ;
mn70:9.4.eng: ‘When someone feels that kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.’

mn70:9.5.pli: api nu me etaṃ, bhikkhave, patirūpaṃ abhavissā”ti?
mn70:9.5.eng: Not knowing this, would it be appropriate for me to say: ‘You should enter and remain in that kind of painful feeling’?”

mn70:9.7.pli: “Yasmā ca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, mayā ñātaṃ diṭṭhaṃ viditaṃ sacchikataṃ phassitaṃ paññāya:
mn70:9.7.eng: “But I have known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom:

mn70:9.8.pli: ‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṃ dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, tasmāhaṃ ‘evarūpaṃ dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ upasampajja viharathā’ti vadāmi.
mn70:9.8.eng: ‘When someone feels that kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.’ Since this is so, that’s why I say: ‘You should enter and remain in that kind of painful feeling.’

mn70:10.1.pli: Mayā cetaṃ, bhikkhave, aññātaṃ abhavissa adiṭṭhaṃ aviditaṃ asacchikataṃ aphassitaṃ paññāya:
mn70:10.1.eng: Now, suppose I hadn’t known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom:

mn70:10.2.pli: ‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṃ adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evāhaṃ ajānanto ‘evarūpaṃ adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ pajahathā’ti vadeyyaṃ;
mn70:10.2.eng: ‘When someone feels this kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’

mn70:10.3.pli: api nu me etaṃ, bhikkhave, patirūpaṃ abhavissā”ti?
mn70:10.3.eng: Not knowing this, would it be appropriate for me to say: ‘You should give up this kind of neutral feeling’?”

mn70:10.5.pli: “Yasmā ca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, mayā ñātaṃ diṭṭhaṃ viditaṃ sacchikataṃ phassitaṃ paññāya:
mn70:10.5.eng: “But I have known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom:

mn70:10.6.pli: ‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṃ adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, tasmāhaṃ ‘evarūpaṃ adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ pajahathā’ti vadāmi.
mn70:10.6.eng: ‘When someone feels this kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’ Since this is so, that’s why I say: ‘You should give up this kind of neutral feeling.’

mn70:10.7.pli: Mayā cetaṃ, bhikkhave, aññātaṃ abhavissa adiṭṭhaṃ aviditaṃ asacchikataṃ aphassitaṃ paññāya:
mn70:10.7.eng: Now, suppose I hadn’t known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom:

mn70:10.8.pli: ‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṃ adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evāhaṃ ajānanto ‘evarūpaṃ adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ upasampajja viharathā’ti vadeyyaṃ;
mn70:10.8.eng: ‘When someone feels that kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.’

mn70:10.9.pli: api nu me etaṃ, bhikkhave, patirūpaṃ abhavissā”ti?
mn70:10.9.eng: Not knowing this, would it be appropriate for me to say: ‘You should enter and remain in that kind of neutral feeling’?”

mn70:11.1.pli: “Yasmā ca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, mayā ñātaṃ diṭṭhaṃ viditaṃ sacchikataṃ phassitaṃ paññāya:
mn70:11.1.eng: “But I have known, seen, understood, realized, and experienced this with wisdom:

mn70:11.2.pli: ‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṃ adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, tasmāhaṃ ‘evarūpaṃ adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ upasampajja viharathā’ti vadāmi.
mn70:11.2.eng: ‘When someone feels that kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.’ Since this is so, that’s why I say: ‘You should enter and remain in that kind of neutral feeling.’

mn70:12.1.pli: Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sabbesaṃyeva bhikkhūnaṃ ‘appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi;
mn70:12.1.eng: Mendicants, I don’t say that all these mendicants still have work to do with diligence.
mn70:12.1.comm: Now the Buddha shows that it is not just him, but others also, who have benefited from sincere practice.

mn70:12.2.pli: na panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sabbesaṃyeva bhikkhūnaṃ ‘na appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:12.2.eng: Nor do I say that all these mendicants have no work to do with diligence.

mn70:12.3.pli: Ye te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū arahanto khīṇāsavā vusitavanto katakaraṇīyā ohitabhārā anuppattasadatthā parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojanā sammadaññāvimuttā, tathārūpānāhaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ ‘na appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:12.3.eng: I say that mendicants don’t have work to do with diligence if they are perfected, with defilements ended, having completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and become rightly freed through enlightenment.

mn70:12.5.eng: They’ve done their work with diligence.

mn70:13.1.pli: Ye ca kho te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū sekkhā appattamānasā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ patthayamānā viharanti, tathārūpānāhaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ ‘appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:13.1.eng: I say that mendicants still have work to do with diligence if they are trainees, who haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring to the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.

mn70:13.3.pli: Appeva nāmime āyasmanto anulomikāni senāsanāni paṭisevamānā kalyāṇamitte bhajamānā indriyāni samannānayamānā—
mn70:13.3.eng: ‘Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties.

mn70:13.4.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyunti.
mn70:13.4.eng: Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

mn70:13.5.pli: Imaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ appamādaphalaṃ sampassamāno ‘appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:13.5.eng: Seeing this fruit of diligence for those mendicants, I say that they still have work to do with diligence.

mn70:14.1.pli: Sattime, bhikkhave, puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
mn70:14.1.eng: Mendicants, these seven individuals are found in the world.

mn70:14.3.pli: Ubhatobhāgavimutto, paññāvimutto, kāyasakkhi, diṭṭhippatto, saddhāvimutto, dhammānusārī, saddhānusārī.
mn70:14.3.eng: One freed both ways, one freed by wisdom, a direct witness, one attained to view, one freed by faith, a follower of teachings, and a follower by faith.

mn70:15.1.eng: And what individual is freed both ways?

mn70:15.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo ye te santā vimokkhā atikkamma rūpe āruppā te kāyena phusitvā viharati paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
mn70:15.2.eng: It’s an individual who has direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements have come to an end.
mn70:15.2.comm: The first two of the seven are both fully perfected arahants. The arahant “freed both ways” is defined by their mastery of formless meditations, which they understand with wisdom (DN 15:36.3, AN 9.45). | “Direct meditative experience” is an oblique rendering of kāyena phusitvā, since in the “formless” meditations, kāya cannot mean “body”. Like other meditative terms, the sense of the word gradually grows more subtle as meditation deepens. In preliminary passages it simply means “the body” as contemplated in meditation. As meditation deepens it takes more of a sense of experience as it happens in the body. Finally, as physical perception fades, kāya loses any sense of materiality and simply means direct personal experience of meditative states or even of Nibbana.

mn70:15.3.eng: This individual is called freed both ways.

mn70:15.4.pli: imassa kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ‘na appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:15.4.eng: And I say that this mendicant has no work to do with diligence.

mn70:15.6.eng: They’ve done their work with diligence.

mn70:16.1.eng: And what individual is freed by wisdom?

mn70:16.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo ye te santā vimokkhā atikkamma rūpe āruppā te na kāyena phusitvā viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
mn70:16.2.eng: It’s an individual who does not have direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. Nevertheless, having seen with wisdom, their defilements have come to an end.
mn70:16.2.comm: Of course these arahants have practiced absorption, which is an essential part of the eightfold path. But because of their strong insight, they have not needed to further develop the ultimate refinement of the formless attainments.

mn70:16.3.eng: This individual is called freed by wisdom.

mn70:16.4.pli: Imassapi kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ‘na appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:16.4.eng: I say that this mendicant has no work to do with diligence.

mn70:16.6.eng: They’ve done their work with diligence.

mn70:17.1.eng: And what individual is a direct witness?
mn70:17.1.comm: The next three may be once-returners, non-returners, or on the path to perfection (AN 3.21:9.3). | A “direct witness” (kāyasakkhi) is distinguished by their mastery of immersion including formless attainments (AN 9.43).

mn70:17.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo ye te santā vimokkhā atikkamma rūpe āruppā te kāyena phusitvā viharati, paññāya cassa disvā ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
mn70:17.2.eng: It’s an individual who has direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. And, having seen with wisdom, some of their defilements have come to an end.

mn70:17.3.eng: This individual is called a direct witness.

mn70:17.4.pli: Imassa kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ‘appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:17.4.eng: I say that this mendicant still has work to do with diligence.

mn70:17.6.pli: Appeva nāma ayamāyasmā anulomikāni senāsanāni paṭisevamāno kalyāṇamitte bhajamāno indriyāni samannānayamāno—
mn70:17.6.eng: ‘Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties.

mn70:17.7.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyāti.
mn70:17.7.eng: Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

mn70:17.8.pli: Imaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, imassa bhikkhuno appamādaphalaṃ sampassamāno ‘appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:17.8.eng: Seeing this fruit of diligence for this mendicant, I say that they still have work to do with diligence.

mn70:18.1.eng: And what individual is attained to view?

mn70:18.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo ye te santā vimokkhā atikkamma rūpe āruppā te na kāyena phusitvā viharati, paññāya cassa disvā ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇā honti, tathāgatappaveditā cassa dhammā paññāya vodiṭṭhā honti vocaritā.
mn70:18.2.eng: It’s an individual who doesn’t have direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. Nevertheless, having seen with wisdom, some of their defilements have come to an end. And they have clearly seen and clearly contemplated with wisdom the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One.

mn70:18.3.eng: This individual is called attained to view.

mn70:18.4.pli: Imassapi kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ‘appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:18.4.eng: I say that this mendicant also still has work to do with diligence.

mn70:18.6.pli: Appeva nāma ayamāyasmā anulomikāni senāsanāni paṭisevamāno kalyāṇamitte bhajamāno indriyāni samannānayamāno—
mn70:18.6.eng: ‘Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties.

mn70:18.7.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyāti.
mn70:18.7.eng: Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

mn70:18.8.pli: Imaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, imassa bhikkhuno appamādaphalaṃ sampassamāno ‘appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:18.8.eng: Seeing this fruit of diligence for this mendicant, I say that they still have work to do with diligence.

mn70:19.1.eng: And what individual is freed by faith?

mn70:19.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo ye te santā vimokkhā atikkamma rūpe āruppā te na kāyena phusitvā viharati, paññāya cassa disvā ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇā honti, tathāgate cassa saddhā niviṭṭhā hoti mūlajātā patiṭṭhitā.
mn70:19.2.eng: It’s an individual who doesn’t have direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. Nevertheless, having seen with wisdom, some of their defilements have come to an end. And their faith is settled, rooted, and planted in the Realized One.

mn70:19.3.eng: This individual is called freed by faith.

mn70:19.4.pli: Imassapi kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ‘appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:19.4.eng: I say that this mendicant also still has work to do with diligence.

mn70:19.6.pli: Appeva nāma ayamāyasmā anulomikāni senāsanāni paṭisevamāno kalyāṇamitte bhajamāno indriyāni samannānayamāno—
mn70:19.6.eng: ‘Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties.

mn70:19.7.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyāti.
mn70:19.7.eng: Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

mn70:19.8.pli: Imaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, imassa bhikkhuno appamādaphalaṃ sampassamāno ‘appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:19.8.eng: Seeing this fruit of diligence for this mendicant, I say that they still have work to do with diligence.

mn70:20.1.eng: And what individual is a follower of teachings?

mn70:20.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo ye te santā vimokkhā atikkamma rūpe āruppā te na kāyena phusitvā viharati, paññāya cassa disvā ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇā honti, tathāgatappaveditā cassa dhammā paññāya mattaso nijjhānaṃ khamanti, api cassa ime dhammā honti, seyyathidaṃ—
mn70:20.2.eng: It’s an individual who doesn’t have direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. And having seen with wisdom, their defilements have not come to an end. And they accept the teachings proclaimed by the Realized One after deliberating them with a degree of wisdom. And they have the following qualities:
mn70:20.2.comm: For “and having seen with wisdom, their defilements have not come to an end”, accept the reading of BJT and PTS, (paññāya cassa disvā āsavā aparikkhīṇā honti). The Mahāsaṅgīti says that “certain” defilements have ended, but it is stream-entry that marks the initial breaking of fetters, while the follower of teachings (and the follower by faith below) are still on the path to stream-entry.

mn70:20.3.eng: the faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

mn70:20.4.eng: This individual is called a follower of teachings.

mn70:20.5.pli: Imassapi kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ‘appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:20.5.eng: I say that this mendicant also still has work to do with diligence.

mn70:20.7.pli: Appeva nāma ayamāyasmā anulomikāni senāsanāni paṭisevamāno kalyāṇamitte bhajamāno indriyāni samannānayamāno—
mn70:20.7.eng: ‘Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties.

mn70:20.8.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyāti.
mn70:20.8.eng: Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

mn70:20.9.pli: Imaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, imassa bhikkhuno appamādaphalaṃ sampassamāno ‘appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:20.9.eng: Seeing this fruit of diligence for this mendicant, I say that they still have work to do with diligence.

mn70:21.1.eng: And what individual is a follower by faith?

mn70:21.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo ye te santā vimokkhā atikkamma rūpe āruppā te na kāyena phusitvā viharati, paññāya cassa disvā ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇā honti, tathāgate cassa saddhāmattaṃ hoti pemamattaṃ, api cassa ime dhammā honti, seyyathidaṃ—
mn70:21.2.eng: It’s an individual who doesn’t have direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form. And having seen with wisdom, their defilements have not come to an end. And they have a degree of faith and love for the Realized One. And they have the following qualities:

mn70:21.3.eng: the faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.
mn70:21.3.comm: Even the least of the noble ones possesses the five spiritual faculties, which include absorption.

mn70:21.4.eng: This individual is called a follower by faith.

mn70:21.5.pli: Imassapi kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ‘appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:21.5.eng: I say that this mendicant also still has work to do with diligence.

mn70:21.7.pli: Appeva nāma ayamāyasmā anulomikāni senāsanāni paṭisevamāno kalyāṇamitte bhajamāno indriyāni samannānayamāno—
mn70:21.7.eng: ‘Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties.

mn70:21.8.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyāti.
mn70:21.8.eng: Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

mn70:21.9.pli: Imaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, imassa bhikkhuno appamādaphalaṃ sampassamāno ‘appamādena karaṇīyan’ti vadāmi.
mn70:21.9.eng: Seeing this fruit of diligence for this mendicant, I say that they still have work to do with diligence.

mn70:22.1.eng: Mendicants, I don’t say that enlightenment is achieved right away.

mn70:22.2.pli: api ca, bhikkhave, anupubbasikkhā anupubbakiriyā anupubbapaṭipadā aññārādhanā hoti.
mn70:22.2.eng: Rather, enlightenment is achieved by gradual training, progress, and practice.

mn70:23.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, anupubbasikkhā anupubbakiriyā anupubbapaṭipadā aññārādhanā hoti?
mn70:23.1.eng: And how is enlightenment achieved by gradual training, progress, and practice?

mn70:23.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, saddhājāto upasaṅkamati, upasaṅkamanto payirupāsati, payirupāsanto sotaṃ odahati, ohitasoto dhammaṃ suṇāti, sutvā dhammaṃ dhāreti, dhatānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthaṃ upaparikkhati, atthaṃ upaparikkhato dhammā nijjhānaṃ khamanti, dhammanijjhānakkhantiyā sati chando jāyati, chandajāto ussahati, ussāhetvā tuleti, tulayitvā padahati, pahitatto samāno kāyena ceva paramasaccaṃ sacchikaroti, paññāya ca naṃ ativijjha passati.
mn70:23.2.eng: It’s when someone in whom faith has arisen approaches a teacher. They pay homage, actively listen, hear the teachings, remember the teachings, examine their meaning, and accept them after deliberation. Then enthusiasm springs up; they make an effort, weigh up, and persevere. Persevering, they directly realize the ultimate truth, and see it with penetrating wisdom.
mn70:23.2.comm: Parallel passages at AN 8.82:2.1 and AN 10.83:4.1 add “ask questions” after “pay homage”, which seems preferable.

mn70:24.1.eng: Mendicants, there has not been that faith,

mn70:24.13.eng: You’re on a bad path, mendicants! You’re practicing the wrong way!
mn70:24.13.comm: The vi- in vippaṭipanna indicates not separation (“lost your way”) but (moral) depravity (eg. Bu Pj 1:9.7.11, SN 3.6:1.4). | The suffix -attha is second plural present of atthi (“you are”), whereas the same form at DN 9:34.19 is imperative (“you should”).

mn70:24.14.pli: Kīva dūrevime, bhikkhave, moghapurisā apakkantā imamhā dhammavinayā.
mn70:24.14.eng: How far these futile men have strayed from this teaching and training!

mn70:25.1.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, catuppadaṃ veyyākaraṇaṃ yassuddiṭṭhassa viññū puriso nacirasseva paññāyatthaṃ ājāneyya.
mn70:25.1.eng: There is an exposition in four statements, which a sensible person would quickly understand when it is recited.
mn70:25.1.comm: This refers to the four injunctions below that begin with “for a faithful disciple”.

mn70:25.2.pli: Uddisissāmi vo, bhikkhave, ājānissatha me tan”ti?
mn70:25.2.eng: I shall recite it for you, mendicants. Try to understand it.”

mn70:25.3.pli: “Ke ca mayaṃ, bhante, ke ca dhammassa aññātāro”ti?
mn70:25.3.eng: “Sir, who are we next to those who understand the teaching?”
mn70:25.3.comm: This idiomatic expression is paralleled at MN 95:34.12.

mn70:26.1.pli: “Yopi so, bhikkhave, satthā āmisagaru āmisadāyādo āmisehi saṃsaṭṭho viharati tassa pāyaṃ evarūpī paṇopaṇaviyā na upeti:
mn70:26.1.eng: “Even with a teacher who values things of the flesh, is an heir in things of the flesh, who lives caught up in things of the flesh, you wouldn’t get into such haggling:

mn70:26.2.pli: ‘evañca no assa atha naṃ kareyyāma, na ca no evamassa na naṃ kareyyāmā’ti, kiṃ pana, bhikkhave, yaṃ tathāgato sabbaso āmisehi visaṃsaṭṭho viharati.
mn70:26.2.eng: ‘If we get this, we’ll do that. If we don’t get this, we won’t do it.’ What then of the Realized One, who lives utterly detached from things of the flesh?

mn70:27.1.pli: Saddhassa, bhikkhave, sāvakassa satthusāsane pariyogāhiya vattato ayamanudhammo hoti:
mn70:27.1.eng: For a faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions, this is in line with the teaching:

mn70:27.2.eng: ‘The Buddha is my Teacher, I am his disciple.

mn70:27.3.eng: The Buddha knows, I do not know.’

mn70:27.4.pli: Saddhassa, bhikkhave, sāvakassa satthusāsane pariyogāhiya vattato ruḷhanīyaṃ satthusāsanaṃ hoti ojavantaṃ.
mn70:27.4.eng: For a faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions, the Teacher’s instructions are nourishing and nutritious.

mn70:27.5.pli: Saddhassa, bhikkhave, sāvakassa satthusāsane pariyogāhiya vattato ayamanudhammo hoti:
mn70:27.5.eng: For a faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions, this is in line with the teaching:

mn70:27.6.pli: ‘kāmaṃ taco ca nhāru ca aṭṭhi ca avasissatu, sarīre upassussatu maṃsalohitaṃ, yaṃ taṃ purisathāmena purisavīriyena purisaparakkamena pattabbaṃ na taṃ apāpuṇitvā vīriyassa saṇṭhānaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
mn70:27.6.eng: ‘Gladly, let only skin, sinews, and bones remain! Let the flesh and blood waste away in my body! I will not relax my energy until I have achieved what is possible by human strength, energy, and vigor.’

mn70:27.7.pli: Saddhassa, bhikkhave, sāvakassa satthusāsane pariyogāhiya vattato dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
mn70:27.7.eng: For a faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions, one of two results can be expected:

mn70:27.8.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā”ti.
mn70:27.8.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”

mn70:27.9.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn70:27.10.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn70:27.10.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
